chapter.title: Performing an System Upgrade (Offline Migration)
chapter.para: This chapter deals with system upgrade (offline migration). In this case, the machine reboots and performs the upgrade. The process is controlled by &yast; and &ay; and not by plain zypper commands.

note.para: Only perform an offline migration on client systems managed by &susemgr; servers. For upgrading the &susemgr; server itself, see . This is a viable method for major version upgrades like from &sle;Â 11 to 12.

step.para: Make sure your &susemgr; and all the clients you want to upgrade have installed all available updates, including the &susemgr; tools. This is absolutely necessary, otherwise the system upgrade will fail.
Then, with the &sumamgr; Web UI proceed as follows:
Create a base channel and, for example, name it SLES 12 SP1 Pool local. Click the Channels tab, then in the left pane Manage Software Channels, and in the upper right corner Create Channel.
Create an autoinstall distribution.
step.remark: emap: Simply replace SP2 with SP3 here?
step.para: For all distributions we want to perform an autoinstallation, we need to create a SLES11 SP2 distribution in &susemgr;. Use the following steps to create one:
Mount the SLES11 SP2 DVD
In the &susemgr; Web interface go to Systems Autoinstallation Distributions and click create new distribution.
Enter a label for your distribution and the mount point.
Select the SP1 base channel.
Create an activation key for your SP2 systems.
In order to switch from the old SLES10emap: rather SLES11? base channel to the new SP2 base channel, we need an activation key. Use the following steps to create one:
Go to Systems Activation Keys and click create new key.
Enter a description for your key.
Enter a key or leave it blank to generate an automatic key.
If you limit the usage, enter your value in the Usage text field.
Select the SLES11 SP1 base channel.
Decide the entitlements.
Click Create Activation Key.
Click Child Channels and select the required channels. Finish with Update key.
Upload an &ay; profile.
Create an &ay; XML file.
step.remark: toms 2012-03-23: This maybe too vague. Where to link to some content how to create an AutoYaST file?

step.para: Go to System Profiles and click upload new kickstart/autoyast file.
Paste the XML content in the text area or select the file to upload. Click Create.
Add autoupgrade=1 in the Kernel parameters of the Details tab and click Update.
Switch to the Variable tab.
Enter in the text field registration_key= and the key name from .
Click Update Variables.

chapter.para: After you have successfully finished the previous procedure, everything is prepared for an upgrade. If you want to upgrade a system, do the following:

step.para: Go to Provisioning Autoinstallation Schedule , and choose the &ay; XML profile you have uploaded in .
Click Schedule Autoinstallation.
Click Finish at the bottom of that page.

chapter.para: Next time the machine asks the &susemgr; server for jobs, it will receive a reinstallation job which fetches Kernel and initrd and writes a new /boot/grub/menu.lst (contains pointers to the new Kernel and initrd).

When the machine boots, it will use the &grub; configuration and boots the new Kernel with its initrd. No PXE boot is required for this process. A shutdown of the machine is initiated as well, effectively 3 minutes after the job was fetched.
